Is it any surprise that whenever the debate shifts to global warming that Wmar has to chime in. He says in post #35.
“Prof. Hans Joachim Schellnhuber of the Potsdam Institute found in 2003, that aside from urban heat islands, that there had not been any global warming such as suggested by the IPCC - OVER THE PAST DECADES (Urban Heat Islands aside):”

NO, he doesn’t say that, he actually says among other things that;
“In the vast majority of stations we did not see indications
for a global warming of the atmosphere. Exceptions
are mountain stations in the Alps where urban warming can be excluded.
Also, in half of the islands we studied, we found
pronounced trends that most probably cannot be attributed to
urban warming. Most of the continental stations where we
observed significant trends are large cities where probably
the fast urban growth in the last century gave rise to temperature
increases.” The next paper Wmar links to is in a language I’m not familiar with, care to translate? He then links to his favorite go to graph which is an ice core temperature proxy graph which says nothing about present day warming since it ends before any 20th century warming. He won’t tell you that though. He goes on to misrepresent the words of the scientists he quotes including Richard Alley as others have pointed out. I get the feeling that he thinks if he is peristent enough posting the same misinformation over and over that people will just throw up their hands in frustration which is what I’ll do now.

#31 Raypierre

Dear Mr. Raypierre,

May I recommend to you the recent article by Syun-ichi Akasofu in Natural Science, Vol.2, No. 11, pp 1211-1224 (2010), dol: 10.4236/ns.2010.211149, entitled "On the Recovery from the Little Ice Age"?

Dr. Akasofu makes a persuasive case that non-anthropogenic factors, specifically a recovery from the Little Ice Age, account for about 0.5 degrees C per century of the observed temperature rise over the instrumentational observation period of 1859 to the present.

This leaves about 0.2 degrees C per century of temperature rise to be accounted for by all other factors, including anthropogenic CO2 changes, land use and land cover changes, the Urban Heat Island effect and black soot.

Dr. Akasofu's prediction is that temperature rise due to recovery from the Little Ice Age will continue, such that total temperature rise by the year 2100 will be on the order of 0.5 degrees C plus or minus 0.2 degrees C.

Well below the 4 degrees C predicted by the IPCC and assorted pundits including, apparently, yourself.

I would be interested in your thoughts on why Dr. Akasofu's prediction should be rejected and the catastrophic predictions in your #31 accepted instead.

A masterwork, Mr. Rich. You write for most of us who are fed up and realize systemic change is needed. The tinkering that President Hope N. Change recommends -- let us know who the big donors are -- is laughable. We need to get rid of the big donors. Period.

One of the elite groups you failed to mention in your stellar essay was The Nine, five of whom have decided that free speech means never having to say who you are but shelling out the big bucks with impunity is A-okay. Justice Scalia's stated attitude is that if you don't like it, change the Constitution. And that's precisely what must be done to "take back America," as the confused tea partiers urge. We need a Constitutional Amendment initiating public financing of campaigns.

Another establishment elite you didn't mention are the media. The media roar against such an amendment will be fierce, because the media are prime beneficiaries in the current system. Even when they offer politicians cut rates on political ads (and they do), the media make a killing during every election cycle. Not only are many media outlets now controlled by right-wing publishers like Rupert Murdoch & Richard Mellon Scaife -- who operate most of their papers at a terrific loss, on, well, paper -- but whatever their editorial viewpoint, they are all beholden to politicians who help underwrite their operations.

So we average Americans have these elements of the elite working against us: the three branches of government, the financial industry, other corporate fat cats, and the media. Our only hope is a proper, peaceful Constitutional revolt. Thomas Jefferson, who wrote that every generation should write its own new Constitution, would urge us to get busy.

The Constant Weader at www.RealityChex.com

The Bipartisanship rant is leaving a sour taste in many a mouth, and not just for the false equivalence between right wing neo-fascists/tea partiers and progressives. You can get knocked over by the propaganda truck of feel-goodism if you're too complacent to notice the reality around you. A friend of mine showed me a little book she had saved from when she and her high school class visited our nations'a capital. The book was published in 1964 and it introduced the reader to the ways of Washington.
All the members of Congress were listed by name and political party....no, that was just in the House.
There wasnt any party affiliation given for the members of the Senate.
The book gave me a glimpse into a world that probably never existed, even in 1964, but I liked the image of 100 Senators who left their labels outside the door when they went to work on the people's business.

Good column, Frank.
Personally, I am really, really, really angry. Among other things, I'd like Bloomberg (by my standards utterly, totally, absolutely and entirely illiterate and barbaric) to stop teaching me.

Our broken government is a three ring circus. One ring, the Supreme Court, is controlled by five corporate lap dogs. The Legislative Branch of our government is a waiting area for career politicians who eventually graduate to the profitable world of corporate lobbying. And finally, we have the Chief Executive, who has the daunting task of pacifying the public with meaningless platitudes while simultaneously making sure that the corporate engine continues to operate unencumbered by any meaningful regulations that may deter the uninterrupted slaughter of the citizenry. The people have been the unwitting victims of a multi-generational transfer of wealth rendering the gains of The New Deal Era moot. Our decades long racket of a faux democratic republic would have made the real and imagined gangsters of the "Boardwalk Empire" cable series blush with embarrassment.
